subject: ACCT
title: Financial Accounting
description: Contemporary accounting and corporate financial reporting. Preparation, interpretation, and analysis of the earnings statement; the statement of financial position; and the statement of cash flows. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AFAM
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Film Works of Spike Lee
description: Introduction to the analysis of film and the study of black popular culture through Spike Lee's films. Close textual analysis of Lee's styles, sources, creative dilemmas, and collaborations. Topics include feminism and the erotic, sex/sexuality/gender, concepts of black leadership, cinematic reflexivity, early film history, race and racism, stereotypes, auteur theory, and questions of audience and authenticity. In class film screenings. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AFAM
title: Race and Sport in US History
long_title: Race and Sport in US History
description: Race relations in the twentieth-century United States explored through the history of American sports. Ways in which organized athletics have shaped racial identity and political protest; the influence of sport on discourses of manhood/womanhood, citizenship, and power; social and political changes from Jack Johnson to Michael Jordan. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AFAM
title: MulticulturalismOrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of ethnicity, race, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: AFAM
title: Civil Conflict  Amer 1176-2005
description: Traces the processes and evolution of civil conflict over the course of American History through five major crucibles of social strife: the American Revolution, women's rights and the fight for women’s suffrage, the Civil War and Reconstruction, the struggle toward Native American sovereignty, and Black Civil Rights. Explores questions of the role and value of civil conflict in the history of American politics and follows common elements and change over time among the five American social conflicts.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AFST
title: History of East Africa
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS; post-independences governments and contemporary politics. This course provides an excellent introduction to East Africa from both academic and experiential perspectives. Students choose HIST or AFST credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $6,100. Course dates: June 14 - July 21.

subject: AFST
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 23 - July 28.

subject: AMST
title: Modern American Literature
description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Henry Adams, Hilda Doolittle, T.S. Eliot, William Faulkner, Ernest Hemingway, Zora Neale Hurston, Langston Hughes, Mina Loy, Ezra Pound, and Gertrude Stein. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: AMST
title: CANCELLED
description: The relationship between objects and empires. Attention to objects themselves as well as to the acts of seeing them and interacting with them on local and global scales. Spaces that house and sell objects; what America's products and technologies say about its society; the valuing of certain objects over others; the function of objectification and object collection in building imperial power. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AMST
title: Race and Sport in US History
long_title: Race and Sport in US History
description: Race relations in the twentieth-century United States explored through the history of American sports. Ways in which organized athletics have shaped racial identity and political protest; the influence of sport on discourses of manhood/womanhood, citizenship, and power; social and political changes from Jack Johnson to Michael Jordan. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AMST
title: MulticulturalismOrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of ethnicity, race, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: AMST
title: Hollywd Novel & Hollywd Movie
long_title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory"—its past, its present, and its future—as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AMST
title: Graphic Memoir
description: The genre of the graphic memoir examined from literary, visual, historical, critical, and creative perspectives. Approaches to the history of the genre; theory of comics and popular culture; theory of memoir; cultural and media studies. Books will include:  Fun Home, by Alison Bechdel; Barefoot Gen, by Keiji Nakazawa; Safe Area Gorazde, by Joe Sacco; Persepolis, by Marjane Satrapi; Stitches, by David Small; Metamouse, by Art Spiegelman; In the Shadow of No Towers, by Art Spiegelman; American Widow, by Alissa Torres, and Understanding Comics, by Scott McCloud. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AMST
title: Civil Conflict Amer 1776-2005
description: Traces the processes and evolution of civil conflict over the course of American History through five major crucibles of social strife: the American Revolution, women's rights and the fight for women’s suffrage, the Civil War and Reconstruction, the struggle toward Native American sovereignty, and Black Civil Rights. Explores questions of the role and value of civil conflict in the history of American politics and follows common elements and change over time among the five American social conflicts.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: AMST
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directorsâ sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ANTH
title: Intro-Cultural Anthropology
description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human thought and behavior. Survey of dynamic ways of life in many different societies; outline of the ways anthropologists have tried to understand societies. Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into how cultural anthropologists do what they do—what problems they encounter and what tools and techniques they use for research and analysis. Film screenings meet W 7-9pm. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ANTH
title: Intro Biological Anthropology
description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ANTH
title: Forensic Anthropology
description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and to the use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ANTH
title: Genesis&CollapseOfOldWorldCivs
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ANTH
title: Southeast Asia in Context
description: Offered in Singapore. The Southeast Asia in Context (SEAiC) Global Summer Program course is a 5-week thematically-based exploration of Southeast Asia's geographical and cultural diversity. It takes advantage of Singapore's position and character as a microcosm of this diversity. SEAiC offers modules on Southeast Asian Studies with archaeological, anthropological and historical concentrations. It also blends classroom instruction on NUS Kent Ridge campus with hands-on fieldwork at sites in Singapore combined with field work in Cambodia and Thailand or Indonesia.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Singapore, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Yale Credit and 1 NUS Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Program fee: $1,200. Course dates: June 21 ÃÂ­ July 23.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Introduction to scholarship on the anthropology of reproduction. Focus on reproductive technologies such as contraceptives, prenatal diagnostics, childbirth technologies, abortion, assisted reproduction, and reproductive technologies that engender harm, such as sex selection and female circumcision. The globalization of reproductive technologies, including social, cultural, legal, and ethical responses. Recommended preparation: ANTH 110b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ANTH
title: Bombay:City, SocietyandCulture
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urban-rural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 12 - July 19.

subject: APHY
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non–science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: APHY
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar which covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ARBC
title: CANCELLED
description: Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ARBC
title: CANCELLED
description: Continuation of ARBC S130. Prerequisite: ARBC 130. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ARBC
title: CANCELLED
description: A basic course in the Iraqi/Gulf dialect of Arabic. Principles of grammar and syntax, foundations for conversation and listening comprehension. Prerequisite: ARBC 130a or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tution: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ARCG
title: Genesis&CollapseOfOldWorldCivs
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ARCH
title: Visualization I

subject: ARCH
title: Building Project

subject: ARCH
title: Visualization IV: Processing

subject: ARCH
title: Rome: Continuity & Change

subject: ARCH
title: Chinese House Courtyard toCity
long_title: The Chinese House from Courtyard to City
description: Offered in Beijing, China. In this joint studio with 3rd year students from Tsinghua University's School of Architecture, students will explore the programmatic, situational and tectonic range of the Chinese courtyard house typology (the fundamental module of pre-1949 Chinese architecture and urbanism). The elasticity and persistence of this type will be explored in three radically different sites: a central Beijing hutong, a rural village and the Forbidden City.  Working in teams, students will use survey, analysis and design exercises to engage each location.  A final project will ask them to synthesize these diverse efforts (and sites) into a contemporary take on the typology. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S241. Prerequisite: an introductory course in architecture or drawing. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from China, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 1. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,050. Course Dates: May 12 - July 3.

subject: ARCH
title: Chinese LandscapeArch&Urbanism
description: Offered in Beijing, China. Major themes in the history and theory of the Chinese built environment will be explored in relation to the typology of the Chinese house. Through a combination of readings, lectures, group and individual site visits, presentations and reports the Chinese House will be used as an armature for a more general introduction to the history, culture, and evolution of Chinese architecture, gardens, and urbanism. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S240. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from China, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 1. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,050. Course Dates: May 12 - July 3.

subject: ARCH
title: Modern Architecture
description: Key developments in modernist architecture and urbanism from 1900 to the present, including art nouveau, constructivism, futurism, monumentalism and utopianism after World War II, and the present clash between new urbanism and neo-avant-gardism. Modernist architecture as an aesthetic response to historical events and forces that shape modern society and the human environment. Includes field trips to view extraordinary examples of modern architecture in New Haven. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ARCH
title: Arch and Ubanism Modern Japan
long_title: Architecture and Urbanism of Modern Japan
description: The development of design philosophies and methodologies in Japanese architecture over the last century. The processes of urbanization and of finding cultural identity as forces that shaped architectural developments. Specific projects and architects used as case studies. Screenings and discussion of Japanese films, with attention to their spatial, social, and cultural contexts. Recommended preparation: an introductory course in the history of art and architecture. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: NorfolkSummerDigitalPhotogrphy

subject: ART
title: Norfolk Summer Printmaking

subject: ART
title: Norfolk Summer Adv Drawing

subject: ART
title: Norfolk Summer Painting

subject: ART
title: Basic Drawing
description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: Introductory Sculpture: Metal
description: Introduction to working with metal. The range of what sculpture might be; creative approaches to perception, creation, and critical analysis; understanding and articulating form in space; responses to current issues in contemporary sculpture. Assignments foster hands-on appreciation of materials and craftsmanship and initiate awareness of the aesthetic and political implications of handmade objects in a digital world. Shops and studio are available during days and evenings throughout the week. Enrollment limited to 12.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: Intro Sculpture: Alternate Med
description: An introductory sculpture course with a primary focus on object making and the incorporation of various techniques and processes.  The course will include workshops focused on video, digital camera use, scanning, basic editing, working with raw files, retouching, color management and ink jet printing. The class will also introduce students to woodworking and welding. Group discussions and critiques, video screenings, readings and workshops complement the studio work. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: Painting Basics
description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Introduction to Graphic Design: Typography for Print and Video
description: A studio introduction to graphic design with emphasis on typography. In addition to typography, topics will include color, visual hierarchy, word/image relationships, and type in motion. Development of a verbal and visual vocabulary to discuss and critique typographic design for print and video or other screen-based work. Programs such as InDesign, Adobe Afteraffects, and Adobe Photoshop may be used for some projects in the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: Intro to Digital Photography
description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital SLR camera and bring it to class. Please e-mail the instructor for more details on specific supplies that must be purchased for the course at an additional expense. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: Intro Interactive Design: WWW
long_title: Introduction to Interactive Design: World Wide Web
description: A studio introduction to typographic communication on the internet. Students will conceive, design, and build a website with a content management system. The relationship between web server, web browser, content author, graphic designer, and user will be emphasized as both technical issues and aesthetic opportunities. Sustainability and evolution of a website over time is emphasized. HTML, CSS, image preparation, and basics of PHP will be taught utilizing the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. No previous knowledge necessary. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ART
title: Animation Basics
description: Introduction to the principals, history, and practice of animation in visual art and film. With a primary focus on production, this course utilizes historical and theoretical developments in 20th and 21st Century animation as a framework for making digital animation. Production focuses primarily on digital stop-animation and compositing, as well as 2D and 3D computer-generated animation. Students gain an understanding of the principals of animation and develop fundamental skill-sets in Apple Final Cut Pro, Adobe After Effects, and Autodesk Maya 2012. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ASTR
title: Planets and Stars
description: For non-science majors. An introduction to stars and planetary systems. Topics include the solar system and extrasolar planets, planet and star formation, and the evolution of stars from birth to death. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ASTR
title: Galaxies and the Universe
description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ASTR
title: IntoObservationalAstrophysics
description: Offered in Santiago, Chile. This six-week course will be held at the University of Chile as part of the Yale-University of Chile collaboration in astronomy and astrophysics education and research. The course is an introduction to astrophysics and to ground-based observing techniques. Extensive observing using research facilities at the Cerro Calan and Cerro Tololo Observatories. Field trips to other major Andean observatories. Students will be able to view the sky through premier telescopes at the clearest observational site in the Southern Hemisphere. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Santiago, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: Physics 180 or equivalent. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Course Dates: June 2 - July 14.

subject: BIS
title: Accelerated Biostats
description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sampling, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through weekly computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package.
requirements: Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: BRST
title: Dickens & British Art

subject: BRST
title: Literature Now, London Edition

subject: BRST
title: Tale of Two CitiesLondon&Paris

subject: BRST
title: Modern British Drama

subject: CDE
title: Advanced SBS
long_title: Accelerated Social and Behavioral Foundations of Health
description: This course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
requirements: Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CDE
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurement of disease occurrence, descriptive epidemiology, randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, ecologic studies, screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies.
requirements: Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CGSC
title: Introduction Cognitive Science
description: A survey of cognitive neuroscience that introduces themes, problems, and methodologies. Topics include perception and encoding, development and plasticity, selective and attentive orienting, learning and memory, cerebral lateralization and language, emotional mechanisms, social cognition, and evolutionary perspectives on the emergence of consciousness. No previous course work in neuroscience required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Pre-college students should take CHEM S114 during Session B. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. John Cramer (CRN 30045) will be in Session A: June 4 - July 6, Narasimhan Ganapathi (CRN 30046) will be in Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Pre-college students should take CHEM S114 during Session B. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. John Cramer (CRN 30045) will be in Session A: June 4 - July 6, Narasimhan Ganapathi (CRN 30046) will be in Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session B: chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acid-base theory, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, introduction to organic chemistry. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Pre-college students should take CHEM S114 during Session B. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry Lab
description: Laboratory techniques required for qualitative and quantitative analysis, synthesis of inorganic compounds, and simple thermodynamic measurements. To accompany or follow CHEM 112 or 114. May not be taken after a higher-numbered laboratory course. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry Lab
description: Laboratory techniques required for qualitative and quantitative analysis, synthesis of inorganic compounds, and simple thermodynamic measurements. To accompany or follow CHEM 113 or 115. May not be taken after a higher-numbered laboratory course. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session A: structure and bonding, chemical energetics, stereochemistry, alkanes, nucleophilic substitution, infrared spectroscopy, alkenes and alkynes, alcohols and ethers. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students only. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session B: aldehydes and ketones, strategies in organic synthesis, carboxylic acid derivatives, carbonyl condensation reactions, sulfur and phosphorus compounds, bifunctional molecules, carbohydrates, organic nitrogen compounds, amino acids and proteins. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students only. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CHEM
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S-220 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S-222/S-223) must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: CHEM
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S-221 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S-222/S-223)must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CLCV
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: CLSS
title: Greek Tragedy in Translation
description: Introduction to classical Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Structure, imagery, and theme; classical Greek stagecraft; the playwrights' responses to Homer; responses to Greek tragedy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CPSC
title: CANCELLED
description: An introduction for nonmajors to some of the most important ideas in computer science: what the computer is; how it works; what it can do and what it cannot do, now and in the future. Topics include algorithms, elementary programming, hardware, language interpretation, software engineering, complexity, models of computation, and artificial intelligence. No previous programming experience required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CPSC
title: CANCELLED
description: An exploration of the myriad ways in which law and technology intersect, with a special focus on broadband, the Internet, and how telecommunications law has evolved to where it is today. Topics include the breakup of the Bell system monopoly, Wi-Fi, FCC regulation of broadband and the Internet, voice over Internet protocol, smartphones and mobile networks. No previous experience with computers or law necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: CZEC
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
long_title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum (with guest lectures by prominent economic and cultural leaders). Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a 4-day film-making practicum: under the supervision of cinematographers Gary Griffin, Josef Lustig and Alice Arnold, students shoot 2 or 3 short films based on their screenplays written in class. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students performing exceptionally in Czech language may qualify for placement above L1 during the 2012-13 academic year. Students choose FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information, e-mail summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: July 5 - August 11.

subject: E&EB
title: Princ of Evol, Ecol, & Beh
long_title: Principles of Evolution, Ecology and Behavior
description: The principles of evolution, ecology, and behavior explained and illustrated by recent advances that have changed the field. Emphasis on important events in the history and key transitions in the organization of life. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students are encouraged to take this course with the laboratory, E&EB S123, which together constitute a full course load. Course in Session A for college students only. Pre-college students should take this course during Session B. Recommended preparation: MCDB 120 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Paul Whitehead (CRN 30063) will teach in Session A: June 4 - July 6, Gail Hartnett (CRN 30064) will teach in Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: E&EB
title: Princ of Evol, Ecol, & Beh
long_title: Principles of Evolution, Ecology and Behavior
description: The principles of evolution, ecology, and behavior explained and illustrated by recent advances that have changed the field. Emphasis on important events in the history and key transitions in the organization of life. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students are encouraged to take this course with the laboratory, E&EB S123, which together constitute a full course load. Course in Session A for college students only. Pre-college students should take this course during Session B. Recommended preparation: MCDB 120 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Paul Whitehead (CRN 30063) will teach in Session A: June 4 - July 6, Gail Hartnett (CRN 30064) will teach in Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: E&EB
title: Lab Prin of Evol, Ecol & Beh
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Evolution, Ecology and Behavior
description: Experimental approaches to organismal and population biology, including study of the diversity of life. For college students only. Concurrently with or after E&EB 122. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: E&EB
title: CANCELLED
description: Study of aquatic habitats of the U.S. central highlands (Appalachians, Ozark and Ouachita mountains). The taxonomic diversity, ecology, biogeography, and evolutionary biology of aquatic animals such as insects, crayfishes, mussels, and fishes. Includes a two-week field trip to observe and sample riverine habitats in Tennessee, Kentucky, and Alabama. Prerequisite: E&EB 122b or equivalent. Recommended preparation: E&EB 225b. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ECON
title: Introductory Microeconomics
description: Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students only. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. CRN 30066 Session A: June 4 - July 6, CRN 30067 Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ECON
title: Introductory Microeconomics
description: Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students only. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. CRN 30066 Session A: June 4 - July 6, CRN 30067 Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ECON
title: Introductory Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. For college students only. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics & Data Analysis l
description: Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Ways to evaluate quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ECON
title: Econ Health & Public Policy
long_title: Economics of Health and Public Policy
description: Application of economic principles to the study of the U.S. health care system. Emphasis on basic principles about the structure of the U.S. system, current problems, proposed solutions, and the context of health policy making and politics. Prerequisite: a course on introductory microeconomics. May not be taken after  ECON 467. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ECON
title: Public Economics
description: The role of government in the economy and in our economic lives. Reasons for government intervention in the market economy and the impact of government expenditure programs and taxation systems on welfare and behavior. Tools of microeconomics applied to issues such as government response to global warming, the impact of redistribution and social insurance on individual behavior, school choice, social security vs. private retirement savings accounts, and government vs. private health insurance. Prerequisite: a course on introductory microeconomics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ECON
title: The Economics of Corruption
description: Corruption as an obstacle to economic efficiency in the application of fiscal policy, in the distribution of assistance, and in business decisions. The economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; alternative policies aimed at reducing corruption. Prerequisite: ECON 108a or b, 110a, or 115a or b, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ECON
title: Welfare Economics PublicPolicy
description: The microeconomic models used to design and evaluate the efficiency and equity of public policies. Case studies from current policy debates to include food stamps, the earned income tax credit, Medicaid, school financing and global warming. After intermediate microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ECON
title: Welfare Econ of Public Policy
description: Offered online. The microeconomic models used to design and evaluate the efficiency and equity of public policies. Case studies from current policy debates to include food stamps, the earned income tax credit, Medicaid, school financing and global warming. After intermediate microeconomics and MATH112 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ECON
title: Topics in Intn'l Economics
description: This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities Global Summer Program. For IARU/GSP students only. Yale students may apply for a limited number of spaces. Partial tuition scholarships available.Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: intermediate microeconomics and macroeconomics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: July 2 - August 10.

subject: EENG
title: The Digital Information Age
description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Elementary computer logic; sensors and actuators; signal processing and design for data transmission; information transmission on the World Wide Web; encryption and steganography. Projects include analysis and design using MS Excel. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENAS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non–science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENAS
title: Data Analysis and Forecasting
description: Quantitative reasoning applied to evaluation of physical formulas and to interpretation of actual data.  Concepts illustrated with models that simulate random data.  Statistical measures predict accuracy of analytic results.  Analysis ranges from paper-and-pencil and scientific calculator to Excel spreadsheets.  Case studies include societal problems involving technological issues, life expectancy and predicting Olympic gold medal performance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENAS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar which covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Timothy Robinson (CRN 30077) teaches during Session A: June 4 - July 6, Briallen Hopper (CRN 30076) and Deborah Tenney (CRN 30078) teach during Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Timothy Robinson (CRN 30077) teaches during Session A: June 4 - July 6, Briallen Hopper (CRN 30076) and Deborah Tenney (CRN 30078) teach during Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Timothy Robinson (CRN 30077) teaches during Session A: June 4 - July 6, Briallen Hopper (CRN 30076) and Deborah Tenney (CRN 30078) teach during Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Reading & Writing Modern Essay
long_title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
description: Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professionals' strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, N. Scott Momaday, George Orwell, Brent Staples, Jonathan Swift, Henry David Thoreau, Tom Wolfe, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, portraiture, nature writing, cultural critique, and formal argument. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Styles Academic & Prof Prose
long_title: Styles of Academic and Professional Prose
description:
A seminar and workshop in the conventions of good writing in a specific field. Each section focuses on one academic or professional kind of writing and explores its distinctive features through a variety of written and oral assignments, in which students both analyze and practice writing in the field.

Students may enroll in one of two sections, which meet in different sessions:
Section 01: Legal Writing; instructor Andrew Ehrgood. Section 02: Writing about Food; instructor Barbara Stuart.

Section 01: Legal Writing; instructor Andrew Ehrgood. Students will develop skills useful to future lawyers and non-lawyers alike: the ability to reason nimbly and argue cogently, consider alternatives without being bogged down by them, and write clearly and precisely. As students learn to identify distinctively lawyerly habits of mind and pen, they will assess the law's appeal and usefulness to themselves as thinkers, writers, and citizens. (CRN 30080) Prerequisite: ENGL 114 or 120 or equivalent, or with permission of instructor. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

Section 02: Writing about Food; instructor Barbara Stuart. Students will read essays by the luminaries of the food world. Students will view popular food films and discuss how these films reflect attitudes toward what we eat. Assignments will focus on what might be called the sub-genres of the food essay: the factors that shape family meals, journalistic essays based upon certain recipes for beloved foods, archival cookbooks, and the food memoir. (CRN 30081) Prerequisite: ENGL 114 or 120 or equivalent, or with permission of instructor. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Writing About Food, Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Styles Academic & Prof Prose
long_title: Styles of Academic and Professional Prose
description:
A seminar and workshop in the conventions of good writing in a specific field. Each section focuses on one academic or professional kind of writing and explores its distinctive features through a variety of written and oral assignments, in which students both analyze and practice writing in the field.
