(CRN 30081) Prerequisite: ENGL 114 or 120 or equivalent, or with permission of instructor. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Writing About Food, Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Reading in American Literature
description: This course serves as both an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present.  We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is “what do we mean when we say ‘American?’”  Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by “literature,” so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one’s own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: Narrative Writing
description: A course that combines both fiction and nonfiction writing, conducted as a workshop. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling - among them, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students will have the opportunity to write short fiction, memoir, and journalistic nonfiction. They may concentrate in one genre, or, if they wish, experiment with genres new to them. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Shakespeare:Comedies&Romances

subject: ENGL
title: ShakespeareHistories&Tragedies
description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-sized critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar.   (The Signet edition,  ordered through The Yale Bookstore, is preferred, but the  Norton genre volumes are especially handsome  substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.)  The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six  one-hour evening screenings, and students are required to attend at least three of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: James Joyce's "Ulysses"
description: An in-depth reading of James Joyce's twentieth-century epic Ulysses, one of the primary texts of literary modernism. Close analysis of Joyce's prose, including examination of its devices and charting of the correspondences and cross-references so important to an understanding of the novel. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Milton
description: Offered online. A study of Milton's major poetry, with attention to his relation to the cultural, social, and political struggles of the Puritan Revolution.  Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures, and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions.  Satisfies pre-1800 requirement. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: Cultural History of Publishing
long_title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the mechanically reproduced book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of first-hand encounters with rare manuscripts, books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: A survey of love poetry in the anglophone tradition.  From Sappho to Shakespeare, Byron to Bishop, verse has been an enduring -- though changing -- vehicle for expressing the emotions of romantic love. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: Modern American Literature
description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Henry Adams, Hilda Doolittle, T.S. Eliot, William Faulkner, Ernest Hemingway, Zora Neale Hurston, Langston Hughes, Mina Loy, Ezra Pound, and Gertrude Stein. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: ENGL
title: Modern European Drama
description: Intensive study of five major playwrights: Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekhov, Brecht, and Beckett. Additional readings in related theater theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: The Bible as Literature
description: Study of the Bible as a literature--as a collection of works exhibiting a variety of attitudes toward the conflicting claims of tradition and originality, historicity and literariness. For Yale College English majors, the course can fulfill a pre-1800 credit upon completion of supplementary assignments in the language of the King James Bible. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: Investigative Journalism
description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the U.S.; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Writing sample of a piece of journalism, or an essay of 5 pages revealing research and writing skills is required, and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: Rev Theater,Film,Dance,Music
long_title: Reviewing Theater, Film, Dance and Music
description: An advanced workshop for writers who want to review the performing arts for newspapers, magazines and other media.  Weekly assignments to review screenings and performances, many of which will be part of New Haven’s International Festival of Arts and Ideas.  Class trip to New York City to review a theatre production. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: A fiction workshop for writers beginning their first novel. Attention to narrative flow, point of view, voice, setting, dialogue, ways to bring characters to life, and methods of revision. Analysis and critique of student manuscripts. Readings from first chapters of contemporary American novels selected for their technique, emotional power, and resonance. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED

subject: ENGL
title: Speaking & Listening

subject: ENVE
title: Introduction to Green Energy
description: Environmental sustainability and the role of green energy in mitigating the impact of greenhouse gases and global warming. Solar thermal, solar photovoltaic, wind, biofuel, hydro, geothermal, and nuclear power; ocean thermal energy conversion and harvesting of tidal power. System-level performance, overall efficiency, cost, and environmental impact of integrated green energy systems. Laboratory experiments on wind-based electricity generation, solar-powered water electrolyzers for hydrogen production, and hydrogen-powered fuel cells. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: ENVE
title: Introduction to Green Energy
description: Offered online. Environmental sustainability and the role of green energy in mitigating the impact of greenhouse gases and global warming. Solar thermal, solar photovoltaic, wind, biofuel, hydro, geothermal, and nuclear power; ocean thermal energy conversion and harvesting of tidal power. System-level performance, overall efficiency, cost, and environmental impact of integrated green energy systems. Technologies for converting waste heat and solid waste into useful energy will be discussed. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: EP&E
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: EPH
title: The Internship
description: The Internship is a degree requirement that is completed in the summer between the first and second academic years. Students work with their faculty advisers and the Office of Career Services to identify suitable placements, which include medical care facilities, community agencies, research projects, laboratories, and other sites engaged in public health activities. The internship experience often serves as a basis for the M.P.H. thesis. The internship is displayed on the transcript with a grade of "S" (Satisfactory) upon completion. A course unit is not given for the summer internship.
requirements: All students must complete a Summer Internship with the exception of those in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. Program. The Summer Internship may be used to complete the Public Health Practice requirement with prior approval from the Office of Community Health.

subject: EVST
title: Sustainability & Institutions
description: This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. For IARU/GSP students only. Yale students may apply for a limited number of spaces. Partial tuition scholarships available. Sustainable development as it relates to institutional change, decision-making processes, and systems thinking.  Throughout the course we will explore the question of how organizations have the capacity to advance principles of sustainable development in their operational functions, mission and growth. The students will engage with Yale as a Living Laboratory throughout the course as well as visit two peer institutions in the region. Course lectures and discussions will draw from YaleÃ¢ÂÂs sustainability commitments to: reduce greenhouse gas emissions, implement a transportation demand management system, serve Ã¢ÂÂsustainable and local foodÃ¢ÂÂ in the residential colleges, build Ã¢ÂÂsustainableÃ¢ÂÂ buildings, integrate sustainability into the master plan framework, reduce waste and manage the urban campus via an ecosystem services framework. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: July 2 - August 10.

subject: F&ES
title: F&ES Internship/Research

subject: FILM
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
long_title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum (with guest lectures by prominent economic and cultural leaders). Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a 4-day film-making practicum: under the supervision of cinematographers Gary Griffin, Josef Lustig and Alice Arnold, students shoot 2 or 3 short films based on their screenplays written in class. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students performing exceptionally in Czech language may qualify for placement above L1 during the 2012-13 academic year. Students choose FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information, e-mail summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: July 5 - August 11.

subject: FILM
title: Yale Sum Film Institute FAMU
long_title: The Yale Summer Film Institute at FAMU
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. An intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film academy of the Czech Republic. Each week, students will explore a key stage in the evolution of film language, from its silent beginnings to its post-modern present, through lectures, screenings, seminars, hands-on workshops and production exercises. During the final two weeks, each student will produce a comprehensive final project, either independently or in collaboration with peers. Instruction is in English. Enrollment limited to 16. Application deadline: February 1. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,150. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,150. Tuition is $6,300 total. Course dates: June 30 - August 4.

subject: FILM
title: Paris and the Cinema
description: Offered in Paris, France. Paris is the cultural capital of cinema. No city has been celebrated in film as frequently and as lovingly as Paris has. This course is an introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth and consumerism of Paris. The class will explore Parisian neighborhoods on city walks, visit two preeminent French cinema institutions (the Cinémathèque Française and the Institut Lumière) and view films together. These films will include Breathless, La Haine, and Amélie. All readings will be in English with further optional readings in French. All films are subtitled in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: July 15 - August 18.

subject: FILM
title: Hollywd Novel & Hollywd Movie
long_title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory"—its past, its present, and its future—as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: FILM
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: FILM
title: CANCELLED
description: Exploration of the musical on film, from The Jazz Singer to Glee. The historical and formal development of the film musical; the expression of meaning through form; how, where, and when the musical has changed; ways in which new forms can create new meanings. Evaluation of musicals within their generic context using the language of film analysis.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: FILM
title: Japanese Cinema & Culture
description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. A broad introduction to Japanese cinema and its interrelations with modern Japanese culture. Surveys the history of Japanese film from the silent era, through the golden ages of the 1930s and the 1950s, up until the present, with particular emphasis on recent decades and films that students can relate to the Japan they experience on the streets. Cinema will be connected to various cultural phenomena, including theater, manga, television, comedy, fan subcultures, minority ethnicities, and literature. The focus will be on investigating the cultural significance of Japanese cinema, both within Japanese culture and in world film, particularly by examining how it has been located in divisions between the traditional and the modern, the national and the transnational, the individual and the group, and the private and the public. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tokyo, costs of room and board in Tokyo, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course Dates: Course dates: July 7 - August 11.

subject: FILM
title: Intensive Filmmaking Workshop
description: An intensive, comprehensive hands-on workshop in which the problems and aesthetics of filmmaking are studied in practice as well as theory. Students learn the narrative film form and its collaborative nature by participating in the production process. By screening classic narrative masterpieces they will gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic as well as develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with their fellow collaborators. The students will begin with seminars, readings and exercises that cover working with actors, script analysis, producing, camera, lighting, sound and editing and then move on to an actual production where as a group they make a short HD movie. Film professionals from various areas of expertise instruct and guide students in the application of industry standards to the exercises projects. The course is fully integrated with FILM S203 to provide filmmakers with a pool of acting talent and enable students to move beyond the technological requirements of the medium. This workshop requires a full daily commitment of the student's time, including 5 hours of classroom instruction, 2 hours of screenings, 1-2 hours of reading homework and workshop projects outside of class time and on weekends.  Enrollment limited to 16. For students in college or beyond only. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/film/filmmaking. Dates: June 18 - July 27.

subject: FILM
title: Acting in Film
description: An intensive, full-time, hands-on workshop that is fully integrated with the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop (Film S-202) which allows the student actor to solve the artistic problems and technical challenges of film acting. Students begin with exercises that acclimate them to the tenets of good acting under the pressures and demands of the filmic medium. Then, with rehearsed scene work, they learn the technical language of cinema and they participate in various filmmaking practices. Their knowledge and techniques are tested by acting in one or more of the films produced by the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop. With the Filmmaking Workshop, the students screen classic narrative masterpieces nightly in order to gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context as well as to develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with fellow collaborators. Screenings, readings, and rehearsals supplement practical application. Daily commitments include, but are not limited to: 3-5 hours daily of classroom instruction, 2.5 hours of nightly screenings, 1-3 hours daily reading, rehearsal and shooting sessions outside of classroom time and on weekends. Enrollment limited to 16. For students in college or beyond only. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/film/acting.html. Dates: June 18 - July 27, M-Th  9.30-12.30; M, W 2-4; Screenings M-Th 7-10 P.M.

subject: FILM
title: The Business of Hollywood
long_title: Money and Media: the Business of Hollywood
description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: FILM
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directorsâ sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: FILM
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Film Works of Spike Lee
description: Introduction to the analysis of film and the study of black popular culture through Spike Lee's films. Close textual analysis of Lee's styles, sources, creative dilemmas, and collaborations. Topics include feminism and the erotic, sex/sexuality/gender, concepts of black leadership, cinematic reflexivity, early film history, race and racism, stereotypes, auteur theory, and questions of audience and authenticity. In class film screenings. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: FILM
title: CANCELLED
description: Cinematic representations of the migrant experience in Greece, Turkey, Italy, US, UK, France, and Australia in the late twentieth century. The immigrant as agent of modernity, mobile human capital, and sexual object. Themes include identity, gender, sexual exploitation and violence, and nationalism and ethnicity.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: FILM
title: Screenwriting
description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: FILM
title: Outlaw Cinema
description: The outlaw as a romanticized, mythic figure in Anglo-American film and culture. Analysis of movies and screenplays whose characters refuse to conform to a restrictive social order in which they have a marginal place. Evolving depictions of the outlaw in mainstream cinema after World War II.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 5 – August 6.

subject: FILM
title: Television and Crime
description: Examines crime drama, reality TV, crime news, crime networks, and crime documentaries.  Analysis of how the news media, community, law enforcement, criminals, and progressive and conservative pundits shape public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process and judicial responsibility, as well as race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: FILM
title: Television Situation Comedy
description: An introductory analysis of the television situation comedy in America from its beginnings in the 1950s to the present time. Exploration of how this popular and powerful genre grew and changed, how it influenced America, and how it was influenced by America in its depictions of family life, race and ethnicity, stereotypes, fantasy, feminism, war, progressive forms of cultural and racial inclusion, and contemporary looks at single life and gay liberation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: FREN
title: Elem & Intermediate French
description: 5 weeks in New Haven, 5 weeks in Paris.  An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French.  This course focuses on developing all language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work and field trips are required.  Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1.  Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - August 11.

subject: FREN
title: Elem & Intermediate French
description: 5 weeks in New Haven, 5 weeks in Paris.  An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French.  This course focuses on developing all language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work and field trips are required.  Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1.  Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - August 11.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate&Advanced French I
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Priority is given to Yale students.  Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate&Advanced FrenchII
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Priority is given to Yale students.  Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Language Practice II
description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: May 28 - June 30.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Culture&Conversation
description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: May 26 - June 30.

subject: FREN
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Beauvais, Amiens, Cluny museum,  and discussion of accompanying historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne. Discussion of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal and intellectual life of the twelfth-century and thirteenth-century Paris. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: July 10 - August 14.

subject: FREN
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Paris, France. Edward Said has characterized exile as "the unhealthy rift forced between a human being and a native place, between the self and its true home." From this discrepant position in between spaces and cultures, exiled authors have developed a unique perspective on the intricate relationship between writing and national belonging. This course aims to introduce and discuss different experiences of exile in relation to gender, race and class as they have been filtered through French and Francophone literature and film throughout the twentieth century. We will examine different aspects of exile: dislocation and hybridity; the journey as metaphor; nostalgia and the trope of home; definitions of national and ethnic identities; diaspora; language and bi-lingualism. Authors and film makers include Tzara, Cesaire, Ionesco, Triolet, Sebbar, Benguigui.  Conducted in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: July 7 - August 11.

subject: FREN
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theatre, and art nouveau cafés in Paris.  Principle authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Mallarmé, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit.  Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 2 - July 7

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German I
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1 . Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German II
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1 . Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: GMAN
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Berlin, Germany. An advanced language course focusing on improving upper level language skills through the exploration of the culture, politics, literature, art, and history of 19th- and 20th-century Berlin. Students will accomplish this through the discussion of current events, films, a novel or play, conducting interviews and visiting sites in Berlin.  Strong class participation expected.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1 . Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: GMAN S140 or the equivalent of two years of college-level German. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Course Dates: June 23 - July 28.

subject: GREK
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: GREK
title: Beg Greek:Review of Grammar
long_title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of GREK S110.  Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141.  Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HIST
title: Race and Sport in US History
long_title: Race and Sport in US History
description: Race relations in the twentieth-century United States explored through the history of American sports. Ways in which organized athletics have shaped racial identity and political protest; the influence of sport on discourses of manhood/womanhood, citizenship, and power; social and political changes from Jack Johnson to Michael Jordan. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HIST
title: Civil Conflict Amer 1776-2005
description: Traces the processes and evolution of civil conflict over the course of American History through five major crucibles of social strife: the American Revolution, women's rights and the fight for women’s suffrage, the Civil War and Reconstruction, the struggle toward Native American sovereignty, and Black Civil Rights. Explores questions of the role and value of civil conflict in the history of American politics and follows common elements and change over time among the five American social conflicts.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HIST
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directorsâ sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HIST
title: Cultural History of Publishing
long_title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the mechanically reproduced book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of first-hand encounters with rare manuscripts, books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HIST
title: From Crusade to Enlightenment
long_title: From Crusade to Enlightenment: Religion and Society in Medieval and Early Modern Europe
description: A survey of major religious debates, battles, and debacles in Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HIST
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HIST
title: History of Southeastern Europe
long_title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,050. Course dates: July 2 - August 3.

subject: HIST
title: Empires of East Asia
description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HIST
title: Islam and Nation
description: Points of interaction between Islam and nationalism in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. The evolution of concepts such as clan loyalty, national identity, ethnic differentiation, and religious brotherhood. Case studies include Iran, China, Indonesia, Egypt, Palestine, the United States, Turkey, and Pakistan.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HIST
title: History of East Africa
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS; post-independences governments and contemporary politics. This course provides an excellent introduction to East Africa from both academic and experiential perspectives. Students choose HIST or AFST credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $6,100. Course dates: June 14 - July 21.

subject: HIST
title: World Politics 1917-1919
description: The emergence of internationalism during the final years of World War I and its immediate aftermath, and the descent toward obsolescence of the empire model in world politics. Responses to Woodrow Wilson's peace diplomacy and the League of Nations; the Russian revolution and the subsequent upheaval across Eurasia; the struggles for Indian, Irish, and Czech independence; the birth of modern nationalism in Asia. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9  - August 10.

subject: HLTH
title: Intn'l Assistance for Health
description: The theory and practice of international assistance for human health issues. The roots of international development assistance following World War II; the Cold War and the so-called âWashington Consensusâ; medical humanitarian relief versus health development; health as a global public good and as a human right; ways in which the practice of health-related international assistance may evolve over the next decade. Recommended preparation: a course in global or public health. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HSAR
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Introduction to History of Art: Prehistory to the Renaissance
description: A history of artistic expression from prehistory to the Renaissance. Selected studies of architecture, sculpture, painting, metalwork, manuscript illumination, etc. Lectures in the classroom and gallery talks in the Yale University Art Gallery, Beinecke Library, and The Cloisters Museum in New York. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HSAR
title: Intro to HSAR: Ren to Modern
long_title: Introduction to History of Art: Renaissance to Modern
description: A survey of Western art from the fifteenth century to the present. Introduction to both the masterpieces of artistic expression and the methods for defining and interpreting those works. Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HSAR
title: Art&Politics:Napoleon toHitler
long_title: Art and Politics: From Napoleon to Hitler
description: Relationships between politics, ideology, and aesthetics in the modern era. The intersection of visual culture and politics, from state-sanctioned art to political propaganda, to art as a medium for political activism. Ways in which images were deployed in the construction and deconstruction of state mythologies and political ideologies. Study of original artworks from the collections of the Yale University Art Gallery and the Yale Center for British Art. Includes an optional weekend field trip to museums in New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HSAR
title: Art and Science
description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HSAR
title: Ten Works of Western Art
description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HSAR
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HSHM
title: Medicine & Religion in America
description: The interplay of medicine and religion in America from the late colonial era through the twentieth century. The influence of factors such as gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, class, regionalism, and medical and religious sectarianism. Changes over time in the fields of physiology, therapeutics, and pathology; varieties of eschatology, periods of religious awakening, and the workings of sectarian emergence and denominational evolution. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HUMS
title: CANCELLED
description: This course is an introduction to key approaches to facilitating individual and organizational change through interactive and improvisational theater. We will examine how approaches such Sociodrama, Playback Theater, Theater of the Oppressed, and Developmental Transformations amongst other practices have been adapted to foster well-being, civic dialogue, and collaborative inquiry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HUMS
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: HUMS
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theatre, and art nouveau cafés in Paris.  Principle authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Mallarmé, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit.  Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 2 - July 7

subject: HUMS
title: Greek Tragedy in Translation
description: Introduction to classical Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Structure, imagery, and theme; classical Greek stagecraft; the playwrights' responses to Homer; responses to Greek tragedy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: HUMS
title: Rome
description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the logical complement and correlation to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Open to Yale students only. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: HUMS 444. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information please contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 3 - July 7.

subject: HUMS
title: Studio Pract Painting&Drawing
long_title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing
description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience.  STUDIO PRACTICE is an intensive  study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work.   It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum*.  All applicants should consult Robert Reed prior to completing the online application. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 3 - July 3

subject: HUMS
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Beauvais, Amiens, Cluny museum,  and discussion of accompanying historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne. Discussion of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal and intellectual life of the twelfth-century and thirteenth-century Paris. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: July 10 - August 14.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5A
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5B
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5B
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: IMED
title: Principles of Clinical Rsrch
description: The purpose of this intensive two-week course is to provide an overview of the objectives, research strategies, and methods of conducting patient-oriented research. Topics include competing objectives of clinical research, principles of observational studies, principles of clinical trials, principles of meta-analysis, interpretation of diagnostic tests, prognostic studies, causal inference, qualitative research methods, and decision analysis. Sessions generally combine a lecture on the topic with discussion of articles that are distributed in advance of the sessions.
requirements: Consent of instructor required. Two weeks, July 25–August 5, 2011.

subject: IMED
title: Intro to Biostatistics
long_title: Introduction to Biostatistics in Clinical Investigation
description: The course provides an introduction to statistical concepts and techniques commonly encountered in medical research. Previous course work in statistics or experience with statistical packages is not a requirement. Topics to be discussed include study design, probability, comparing sample means and proportions, survival analysis, and sample size/power calculations. The computer lab incorporates lecture content into practical application by introducing the statistical software package SPSS to describe and analyze data.
requirements: Consent of instructor required. Two weeks, July 11–22, 2011.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: ITAL
title: Italian Lang&Cinema in Tuscany
long_title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, The Adventures of Pinocchio, My Friends, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, The Man Who Will Come, Mar nero, and the Florentine episode of Paisà. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 25 - July 28.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian ll
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 140. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150.  Course dates:June 4 - July 28.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 (Intermediate Italian I). Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150.  Course dates:June 4 - July 28.

subject: ITAL
title: Italian Renaissance Theater
description:
Offered in Siena, Italy. The course studies a number of plays of the Italian Renaissance within the context of theoretical debates on the genre and against the realities of the social world in the fifteen and sixteen centuries Tuscany.  More precisely, it will take as its point of departure Poliziano's play and will study the impact of both Aristotle's Poetics on the theatrical premises of the theater and the Florentine intellectual life of the late 15th century. We will then read two plays of Machiavelli, the Mandragola and the Clizia by relating them to the theatrical spectacles of Italian 16th century politics (and the Prince).
Because so many plays, such as Cecchi's L'assiuolo, were performed not only for festive tides such as Carnival and Epiphany, but also be popular and courtly entertainment we will read Ariosto's Negromante in the context of the traditions of sacre rappresentazioni, and the commedia dell'arte. Taught entirely in Italian. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students. Prerequisite: ITAL 140 or 145. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150.  Course dates: June 23 - July 28.

subject: JAPN
title: Japanese Cinema & Culture
description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. A broad introduction to Japanese cinema and its interrelations with modern Japanese culture. Surveys the history of Japanese film from the silent era, through the golden ages of the 1930s and the 1950s, up until the present, with particular emphasis on recent decades and films that students can relate to the Japan they experience on the streets. Cinema will be connected to various cultural phenomena, including theater, manga, television, comedy, fan subcultures, minority ethnicities, and literature. The focus will be on investigating the cultural significance of Japanese cinema, both within Japanese culture and in world film, particularly by examining how it has been located in divisions between the traditional and the modern, the national and the transnational, the individual and the group, and the private and the public. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tokyo, costs of room and board in Tokyo, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course Dates: Course dates: July 7 - August 11.

subject: LATN
title: Beg Latin: Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120. No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: #3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: LATN
title: Beg Latin: Review of Grammar
long_title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: LITR
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Beauvais, Amiens, Cluny museum,  and discussion of accompanying historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne. Discussion of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal and intellectual life of the twelfth-century and thirteenth-century Paris. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: July 10 - August 14.

subject: LITR
title: Translation:Liter & Practice
description: Exploration of various theoretical and practical problems in translation. Topics include the responsibility of the translator to the text, the author and the reader; the reliability of translation as a literary mode; the transmission or perversion of culture via translation; and the specific problems involved with the translation of various genres (poetry, drama, fiction, non-fiction). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: LITR
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theatre, and art nouveau cafés in Paris.  Principle authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Mallarmé, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit.  Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 2 - July 7

subject: LITR
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: LITR
title: Beauty, Justice, Evil
description: Examination of ways in which film, art, and philosophy replicate and distribute beauty. The relationship between beauty and truth; beauty and the promise of happiness; the relation of detection to justice; how justice asserts that love is reciprocal; the machination of evil and its relation to envy; evilâs refusal to be attentive to otherness. Readings from both philosophical and literary texts. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MATH
title: CalculusFunctionOneVariable I
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra and pre-calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MATH
title: CalculusFunctionOneVariableII
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MATH
title: IntroFunctionsSeveralVariables
long_title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus-Several Variables
long_title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MCDB
title: Principles of MCDB
long_title: Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
description: Introduction to biochemistry, genetics, cell biology, and development. Emphasis on the cell as the basic unit of life; the cell's composition, functions, replication, and differentiation. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students should take this course with the laboratory, MCDB S121, which together constitute a full course load. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MCDB
title: Lab for Principles of MCDB
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken concurrently with or after MCDB 120. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MCDB
title: How The Brain Works
description: The biology of the brain as it relates to various functions and dysfunctions. Gross anatomy and cellular composition of nervous system tissue; development of the nervous system, including its organization into motor, sensory, and other systems; the biology underlying complex processes such as learning, memory, and mood regulation; psychoactive and performance-enhancing drugs in the brain; disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, autism, and depression. For non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MCDB
title: Cell Biology
description: A comprehensive interactive course in cell and molecular biology.  Emphasis on principles of cell function and translational biomedical experiments.  Prerequisite: MCDB 120 or permission from the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: MGRK
title: CANCELLED
description: Cinematic representations of the migrant experience in Greece, Turkey, Italy, US, UK, France, and Australia in the late twentieth century. The immigrant as agent of modernity, mobile human capital, and sexual object. Themes include identity, gender, sexual exploitation and violence, and nationalism and ethnicity.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: MMES
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 23 - July 28.

subject: MMES
title: Intro to Middle East Politics
description: Offered online. An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MUSI
title: Intro to the Elements of Music
long_title: Introduction to the Elements of Music
description: The fundamentals of musical language (notation, rhythm, scales, keys, melodies, and chords), including writing, analysis, singing, and dictation. Intended for students who have no music reading ability. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MUSI
title: How to Listen  Classical Music
long_title: How to Listen to Classical Music
description: Offered online. Want to know more about MozartÂ¬, Bach, or Beethoven and their music?  This course will not only introduce you to the lives of these great composers and many others, but more important, teach you how to listen and appreciate their masterpieces.   Using listening techniques derived from an in-class study of pop music, students will develop a âcomfort zoneâ for classical music, and thereby begin to make classical music an important part of their lives.   Classes will be challenging but accessible to all.   No previous musical experience is requiredâexcept a love of music, popular and/or classical. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: MUSI
title: Jazz and Race in America
description: Offered online. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: MUSI
title: Amer Popular Music Since 1945
description: Investigation of popular music as an expression of cultural identities in the United States from the end of World War II to the present, including genres such as blues, rock, soul, funk, alternative, and rap. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: OPRS
title: Managing Supply Chains
description:
Study of the management of materials, information, and financial flows in a network consisting of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, and customers. Topics covered include logistics network configuration; risk pooling; multi-echelon inventory systems; value of information in supply chains; coordination of the supply chain using contracts and other mechanisms; distribution strategies for the supply chain; and issues related to product design. Limited enrollment. No prerequisites.

This course is offered in residence at Yale in conjunction with three other universities: Ben Gurion (Israel), Bilkent (Turkey), Maastricht (Netherlands). Six students will be admitted from each university, making up a total student body of 24. The class will then be divided into 6 teams, each team consisting of 4 students (one from each university), for discussion, writing, and presenting case studies. Yale students will meet on-campus on Mondays for lectures that will be videoconferenced to the students in the other countries. Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday meetings will be online with teammates from the other three universities. Friday meetings will be on-campus for a review of that weekâs work with fellow Yale students.

1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 13.
