subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHIL
title: First-Order Logic
description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PHIL
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHIL
title: Eastern Philosophy
description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PHIL
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHYS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non–science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar which covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics
description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers vectors, kinematics, Newton’s laws of motion, oscillations and waves, gravitation, elasticity, statics, diffusion, fluids, and thermodynamics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre?college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 150 and 151 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics
description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre?college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 150 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S150, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S151, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,575. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro International Relations
description: A study of contemporary political issues that are international in scope: war, globalization, terrorism, human rights, immigration, development, and the environment. Topics include relations between states, international organizations such as the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, and the World Bank, and nongovernmental bodies, including multinational corporations, nonprofit organizations, and armed groups. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro-Political Philosophy
description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philocophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro to Comparative Politics
description: Introduction to politics and political life outside the United States. State formation and nationalism, the causes and consequences of democracy, ethnic competition and conflict, colonial origins of economic development, and political violence and terrorism. Some attention to methodological issues, including research design and quality of argumentation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: Democracy Violence Americas
long_title: The Democracy of Violence in the Americas
description: This course focuses on a post-9/11 analysis of transnational threats. The regional concept of ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂmultidimensional securityÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ points out traditional and new threats to states in the Western Hemisphere such as: terrorism, organized crime, corruption, asset laundering, illicit trafficking in weapons, drugs and people; and contributes, inter alia, to the consolidation of peace, development, social justice, the defense of human rights, and democracy promotion. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Religion and Violence
description: Exploration of how violence and religion intersect historically, sociologically, and analytically. Comparative examination of religion and conflict over time and space. Focus on the major monotheistic religions, with some attention to classical polytheistic societies. Definitions of religious violence; whether religious violence is a different topic from religion and violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Intn'lDimensionsDemocratizatn
description: Investigation of the role played by international factors such as socialization, coercion, and emulation in the current wave of democratizations around the world. Focus on the extent to which democratic processes can be affected from the outside. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: US Strategy After the Cold War
long_title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War
description: American grand strategy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The ability of the United States to project its power around the world. Constraints on and challenges to American power in the international political system. The effect of nuclear weapons on the workings of a unipolar world. The possible emergence of peer competitors in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Intrnatl HumanRights&Politics
description: International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Institutns&ReprsentatnUSDmcrcy
long_title: Institutions and Representation in American Democracy
description: Ways in which institutions affect the functioning of democracy in the United States. Focus on representation of citizens' preferences in the public sphere. Institutions studied include primary elections, redistricting, campaign finance, early voting, multimember districts, pivotal politics, legislative committees, term limits, and term lengths. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: Journalism Liberalsm Democracy
description: The news media's role in configuring the democratic public sphere, from the early synergy of print capitalism and liberalism through the corporate consolidation of mass media and the recent fragmentation and fluidity of "news." Classical-humanist and civic-republican responses to these trends. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Crime & Punishment
description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PLSC
title: The American Presidency
description: A survey of the historical development of the executive branch of the American national government; an examination of the politics of presidential leadership; and consideration of how the development of the executive branch has affected presidential politics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Terrorism, Law, Morality
description: Legal and moral issues in democracies' responses to terrorism. What the term "terrorism" denotes and why and when it is used; U.S. law regarding material support for terrorism; the targeted killing of persons in a global battlefield; how terrorism compares morally to other forms of political violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro to Middle East Politics
description: Offered online. An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. Enorllment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PORT
title: Elem Port Romance Lang Speaker
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
description: First two weeks of the course in New Haven, two weeks in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S122 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another romance language.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janeiro, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300.  Course Dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: PORT
title: Elem Port Romance Lang Speaker
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
description: First two weeks of the course in New Haven, two weeks in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another romance language.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janeiro, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300.  Course Dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: First two weeks of the course in New Haven, two weeks in São Jose do Rio Preto, São Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro.  Conducted in Portuguese. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S140 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300.  Course Dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: First two weeks of the course in New Haven, two weeks in São Jose do Rio Preto, São Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro.  Conducted in Portuguese. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S130 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300.  Course Dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: PORT
title: Introduction to Brazil
description: First two weeks of the course in New Haven, two weeks in Paraty or Sao Jose do Rio Preto, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in English at Yale and Portuguese in Brazil. Major themes and figures in Brazil's cultural profile emphasizing historical and cultural perspectives. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112/S122 or PORT S130/S140. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S112/S122 or PORT S130/S140 for tuition. Course Dates: June 4 - July 28

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Offered online. A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PSYC
title: Intro Cognitive Neuroscience
description: A survey of cognitive neuroscience that introduces themes, problems, and methodologies. Topics include perception and encoding, development and plasticity, selective and attentive orienting, learning and memory, cerebral lateralization and language, emotional mechanisms, social cognition, and evolutionary perspectives on the emergence of consciousness. No previous course work in neuroscience required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PSYC
title: Human Emotion
description: Introduction to theories of human emotion from diverse fields in psychology. How emotions are perceived, generated and experienced; culture and gender differences; emotional development over the life span and across species; emotions in social relationships; emotion regulation, including dysregulation in mental illnesses. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PSYC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PSYC
title: Developmental Psychology
description: Introduction to research and theory on the development and changes in perception, cognition, emotion and social functioning across the life span. Focus on birth through adulthood. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PSYC
title: Sex, Evolution, & Human Nature
description: How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. May not be taken for credit after PSYC 171b. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: PSYC
title: Sex, Evolution, & Human Nature
description: Offered online. How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. May not be taken for credit after PSYC 171b. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: PSYC
title: Abnormal Psychology
description: Study of the major forms of psychopathology that appear in childhood and adult life. Topics include the symptoms of mental disorders; the etiology of disorders from a variety of perspectives (psychological, biological, and sociocultural); and issues pertaining to diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: The religious traditions of South Asia from 1500 B.C.E. to the present. Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism, and Sikhism, as well as forms of Islam, Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism in the region. South Asian religions as the historical products of various discourses from both inside and outside the traditions. The continuous evolution of the insider-outsider dynamic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: RLST
title: The Religion of Islam
description: An introduction to Islam. Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: RLST
title: Christians&MuslimsinArabWorld
long_title: Christians and Muslims in the Arab World
description: History of Arabic-speaking Christians and Christian-Muslim encounters from the rise of Islam to the modern age. Topics include views of Jesus and Christianity in early Islam; initial Christian responses to the Arab conquest; medieval Arabic Christian theology, philosophy, and ethics; the impact of the Crusades; religion and politics in modern Palestine and Egypt; and the experience of Arabic Christians after 9/11. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: Examination of the Bhagavad Gita, including the background and meaning of this influential Vaisnava bhakti text. Emphasis on the work's function in the religious fabric of India. Major interpretations of the text during the past two millennia. All readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: RLST
title: From Crusade to Enlightenment
long_title: From Crusade to Enlightenment: Religion and Society in Medieval and Early Modern Europe
description: A survey of major religious debates, battles, and debacles in Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 120. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 4 - July 31.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 120. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S130 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 4 - July 31.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 140. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S151 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 4 - July 31.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 140. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S150 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 4 - July 31.

subject: RUSS
title: Fourth Year Russian
description: Five weeks in St. Petersburg (no language classes in New Haven). An intensive "language-abroad" course featuring study of Russian at the fourth year level. Students stay with a Russian family and receive language training (7 hours per week), further developing all four language skills and immediately putting them to practice during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 151. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 24 - July 31.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Culture
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. This course explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe.  Since then, the city has been seen to embody all of the contradictions of Russia: East vs. West, imperial grandeur vs. the pathos of the little man, nature vs. civilization, free will vs. fate. The course considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complimented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St. Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S 150/151.  Course Dates: June 4 - July 31.

subject: SAST
title: Bombay:City, SocietyandCulture
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urban-rural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 12 - July 19.

subject: SCIE
title: Scientific Res: Process&Presen
description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative informations. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,150. June 11 - August 10.

subject: SOCY
title: Fndtns of Modern Social Theory
description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: SOCY
title: Global Public Health
description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: SOCY
title: MulticulturalismOrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of ethnicity, race, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: SOCY
title: Inequality&DevianceContmprySoc
long_title: Inequality and Deviance in Contemporary Society
description: The sociology of deviance and its relationship to inequality. Focus on contemporary society, with some attention to the history of aberrant identities. Sociological theories of deviance; social inequality as the consequence of deviance and vice versa; the construction of aberrant identities; ways in which individuals and groups cope with the stigma of deviance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: SOCY
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 23 - July 28.

subject: SOCY
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,050. Course dates: July 2 - August 3.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish I
description: For students who wish to begin study of the Spanish language. Development of basic skills in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing through a functional approach to the teaching of spanish grammar. Includes an introduction to the cultures (traditions, art, literature, music) of the Spanish-speaking world. Audio-visual materials are incorporated into class sessions. Conducted in Spanish. To be followed by SPAN S120.  Credit only on completion of SPAN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish ll
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Class sessions incorporate short authentic texts in Spanish, audiovisual materials, and film. Cultural topics of the Spanish-speaking world (traditions, art, literature, music) are included. Conducted in Spanish. After SPAN S110 or in accordance with placement results. Admits to SPAN 130 or 145. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks abroad. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from the site, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Bilbao CRN 30239, in Quito CRN 30242) and S248 or S249 (in Bilbao SPAN S248 CRN 30240 Spain, 1936 to the Present, or in Quito SPAN S249 CRN 30243 Ecuador Pre-Columbian to Present). Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: SPAN
title: Theater and Poetry Workshop
description: Offered in Buenos Aires, Argentina. This course explores the dynamics of figurative and theatrical language through close reading of early and contemporary Spanish and Latin American dramatic texts. The selected plays reflect on the topics of gender, identity, love, politics, torture and violence. Students participate in an acting workshop and attend live performances of Argentine theater. Prerequisite: SPAN 150 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Buenos Aires, room and board costs in Argentina, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150.  Course dates: June 2 - July 7.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain 1936 to Present
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Founded in 1886, the university continues to be one of the most important institutions of higher education of the Basque Country and Spain. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: SPAN
title: Ecuador Pre-Columbian to Pres
long_title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Quito, Ecuador. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.

subject: STCY
title: Intro to the Study of the City
long_title: Introduction to the Study of the City
description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance.  Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance.  Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Prerequisite: SWAH 130 (Intermediate Kiswahili I) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Course dates: June 2 - July 14.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: This course is an introduction to key approaches to facilitating individual and organizational change through interactive and improvisational theater. We will examine how approaches such Sociodrama, Playback Theater, Theater of the Oppressed, and Developmental Transformations amongst other practices have been adapted to foster well-being, civic dialogue, and collaborative inquiry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: THST
title: Greek Tragedy in Translation
description: Introduction to classical Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Structure, imagery, and theme; classical Greek stagecraft; the playwrights' responses to Homer; responses to Greek tragedy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: THST
title: Modern European Drama
description: Intensive study of five major playwrights: Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekhov, Brecht, and Beckett. Additional readings in related theater theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Food and Culture
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
description: Introduction to scholarship on the anthropology of reproduction. Focus on reproductive technologies such as contraceptives, prenatal diagnostics, childbirth technologies, abortion, assisted reproduction, and reproductive technologies that engender harm, such as sex selection and female circumcision. The globalization of reproductive technologies, including social, cultural, legal, and ethical responses. Recommended preparation: ANTH 110b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
description: Study of works that have as their theme gay and lesbian experience and identity since the late nineteenth century. Works include fiction and autobiographical texts, historical and sociological materials, texts on queer theory, and films. Focus on modes of representing sexuality and on the intersections between sexuality and race, ethnicity, class, gender, and nationality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.

subject: WGSS
title: Graphic Memoir
description: The genre of the graphic memoir examined from literary, visual, historical, critical, and creative perspectives. Approaches to the history of the genre; theory of comics and popular culture; theory of memoir; cultural and media studies. Books will include:  Fun Home, by Alison Bechdel; Barefoot Gen, by Keiji Nakazawa; Safe Area Gorazde, by Joe Sacco; Persepolis, by Marjane Satrapi; Stitches, by David Small; Metamouse, by Art Spiegelman; In the Shadow of No Towers, by Art Spiegelman; American Widow, by Alissa Torres, and Understanding Comics, by Scott McCloud. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
